multiple_dispatch.description: Multiple dispatch allows functions to have different implementations based on the types of all arguments, enabling elegant and performant polymorphism
multiple_dispatch.whenToUse: Use as the primary mechanism for polymorphism, when implementing generic algorithms, creating extensible APIs, or building type-specific optimizations
multiple_dispatch.example:
# Basic multiple dispatch
function area(shape)
    error("area not implemented for $(typeof(shape))")
end

# Specific implementations for different types
area(r::Rectangle) = r.width * r.height
area(c::Circle) = π * c.radius^2
area(t::Triangle) = 0.5 * t.base * t.height

# Multiple dispatch on multiple arguments
function combine(x::Number, y::Number)
    return x + y
end

function combine(x::String, y::String)
    return x * y  # String concatenation in Julia
end

function combine(x::Vector, y::Vector)
    return vcat(x, y)
end

# Type parameters and constraints
function dot_product(v1::Vector{T}, v2::Vector{T}) where T<:Number
    length(v1) == length(v2) || throw(DimensionMismatch("vectors must have same length"))
    return sum(v1 .* v2)
end

# Diagonal dispatch for special cases
function process(x::T, y::T) where T
    println("Processing two values of the same type: $T")
    return x, y
end

function process(x::Integer, y::Integer)
    println("Special handling for integers")
    return x + y
end

# Varargs and optional arguments
function aggregate(op::Function, x::Number, rest::Number...)
    result = x
    for val in rest
        result = op(result, val)
    end
    return result
end

# Method ambiguity resolution
function priority_dispatch(x::Integer, y::Real)
    return "Integer-Real"
end

function priority_dispatch(x::Real, y::Integer)
    return "Real-Integer"
end

# Need to resolve ambiguity for (Integer, Integer)
function priority_dispatch(x::Integer, y::Integer)
    return "Integer-Integer"
end

# Dynamic dispatch with type stability
function type_stable_dispatch(data::Vector)
    # Compiler can optimize when return type is predictable
    s = zero(eltype(data))  # Type-stable initialization
    for x in data
        s += process_element(x)  # Dispatches based on element type
    end
    return s
end

process_element(x::Float64) = x
process_element(x::Int) = float(x)
process_element(x::Complex) = real(x)

parametric_types.description: Parametric types allow creating generic data structures and functions that work with different types while maintaining type safety and performance
parametric_types.whenToUse: Use when building generic containers, implementing algorithms that work across types, creating type-safe abstractions, or optimizing performance with type specialization
parametric_types.example:
# Parametric composite types
struct Point{T<:Real}
    x::T
    y::T
end

# Parametric with multiple parameters
struct Matrix2D{T<:Number, S<:AbstractStorage}
    data::S
    rows::Int
    cols::Int
    
    function Matrix2D{T,S}(data::S, rows::Int, cols::Int) where {T<:Number, S<:AbstractStorage}
        length(data) == rows * cols || throw(ArgumentError("Data size mismatch"))
        new{T,S}(data, rows, cols)
    end
end

# Parametric abstract types
abstract type AbstractContainer{T} end

struct Vector{T} <: AbstractContainer{T}
    data::Array{T,1}
end

struct SparseVector{T} <: AbstractContainer{T}
    indices::Vector{Int}
    values::Vector{T}
    length::Int
end

# Type parameters in functions
function zero_array(::Type{T}, dims...) where T
    return zeros(T, dims...)
end

# Constrained type parameters
function safe_divide(x::T, y::T) where T<:AbstractFloat
    y == zero(T) && throw(DivideError())
    return x / y
end

# Multiple type parameters with relationships
function convert_array(::Type{Array{T,N}}, a::Array{S,N}) where {T,S,N}
    return T[convert(T, x) for x in a]
end

# UnionAll types
const VecOrMat{T} = Union{Vector{T}, Matrix{T}}

function sum_elements(x::VecOrMat{T}) where T<:Number
    return sum(x)
end

# Parametric methods with trait-like behavior
struct GPU end
struct CPU end

function compute(::Type{GPU}, data::Array{T}) where T
    println("GPU computation for $(T)")
    # GPU-specific implementation
end

function compute(::Type{CPU}, data::Array{T}) where T
    println("CPU computation for $(T)")
    # CPU-specific implementation
end

# Variance and type bounds
struct Container{T}
    value::T
end

# Covariant-like behavior through methods
Base.convert(::Type{Container{T}}, c::Container{S}) where {T,S<:T} = Container{T}(convert(T, c.value))

# Type-stable constructors
struct OptimalArray{T,N}
    data::Array{T,N}
    
    # Inner constructor ensures type stability
    function OptimalArray(data::Array{T,N}) where {T,N}
        new{T,N}(data)
    end
end

# Parametric type aliases
const Point2D = Point{Float64}
const IntVector = Vector{Int}

metaprogramming.description: Metaprogramming in Julia allows code generation and transformation at parse time or compile time, enabling powerful abstractions and domain-specific languages
metaprogramming.whenToUse: Use when eliminating boilerplate code, creating DSLs, generating optimized code for specific cases, or building macro-based APIs
metaprogramming.example:
# Basic macro for timing
macro timed(ex)
    quote
        local t0 = time()
        local val = $(esc(ex))
        local t1 = time()
        println("Elapsed time: ", t1-t0, " seconds")
        val
    end
end

# Using the macro
# @timed begin
#     sleep(1)
#     42
# end

# Code generation with eval
for op in (:+, :-, :*, :/)
    @eval begin
        function vectorized_op(a::Vector{T}, b::Vector{T}, ::typeof($op)) where T
            return [$op(a[i], b[i]) for i in 1:length(a)]
        end
    end
end

# Macro for creating getters/setters
macro define_property(name, T)
    field = Symbol("_", name)
    getter = name
    setter = Symbol("set_", name, "!")
    
    quote
        $field::$T
        
        function $(esc(getter))(obj)
            return obj.$field
        end
        
        function $(esc(setter))(obj, value::$T)
            obj.$field = value
            return obj
        end
    end
end

# Expression manipulation
function optimize_expression(ex::Expr)
    if ex.head == :call && ex.args[1] == :* && ex.args[3] == 2
        # Replace x * 2 with x + x
        return :( $(ex.args[2]) + $(ex.args[2]) )
    end
    
    # Recursively process sub-expressions
    return Expr(ex.head, [optimize_expression(arg) for arg in ex.args]...)
end

optimize_expression(x) = x  # Base case for non-expressions

# Generated functions for compile-time computation
@generated function static_unroll(f::F, ::Val{N}) where {F,N}
    exprs = [:(f($i)) for i in 1:N]
    return quote
        $(exprs...)
        nothing
    end
end

# Staged programming with generated functions
@generated function efficient_dot(x::NTuple{N,T}, y::NTuple{N,T}) where {N,T}
    terms = [:(x[$i] * y[$i]) for i in 1:N]
    return :(+($(terms...)))
end

# Macro for pattern matching
macro match(expr, cases...)
    result = :(error("No matching case"))
    
    for case in reverse(cases)
        pattern, action = case.args[1], case.args[2]
        condition = pattern_to_condition(expr, pattern)
        result = :(if $condition
            $action
        else
            $result
        end)
    end
    
    return esc(result)
end

# String interpolation in macros
macro sql(query)
    # Parse SQL-like syntax into Julia code
    return quote
        # Implementation would parse the SQL string
        println("Executing SQL: ", $(string(query)))
    end
end

# Symbol manipulation
macro create_constants(prefix, values...)
    assignments = []
    for (i, val) in enumerate(values)
        name = Symbol(prefix, "_", i)
        push!(assignments, :( const $(esc(name)) = $val ))
    end
    return quote
        $(assignments...)
    end
end

traits_pattern.description: Traits in Julia are a pattern for grouping types by behavior rather than inheritance, enabling flexible and extensible interfaces
traits_pattern.whenToUse: Use when you need to define behavior across unrelated types, implement interface-like contracts, or enable generic programming based on capabilities
traits_pattern.example:
# Holy trait pattern
abstract type IteratorSize end
struct HasLength <: IteratorSize end
struct HasShape <: IteratorSize end
struct IsInfinite <: IteratorSize end
struct SizeUnknown <: IteratorSize end

# Trait function
IteratorSize(::Type) = SizeUnknown()
IteratorSize(::Type{<:Array}) = HasShape()
IteratorSize(::Type{<:AbstractRange}) = HasLength()

# Dispatch on traits
function my_collect(itr)
    _collect(IteratorSize(typeof(itr)), itr)
end

function _collect(::HasLength, itr)
    n = length(itr)
    arr = Vector{eltype(itr)}(undef, n)
    for (i, x) in enumerate(itr)
        arr[i] = x
    end
    return arr
end

function _collect(::SizeUnknown, itr)
    arr = eltype(itr)[]
    for x in itr
        push!(arr, x)
    end
    return arr
end

# Trait-based dispatch for algorithms
abstract type IndexStyle end
struct IndexLinear <: IndexStyle end
struct IndexCartesian <: IndexStyle end

IndexStyle(::Type) = IndexCartesian()
IndexStyle(::Type{<:Array}) = IndexLinear()
IndexStyle(::Type{<:AbstractRange}) = IndexLinear()

function efficient_sum(A::AbstractArray)
    _sum(IndexStyle(typeof(A)), A)
end

function _sum(::IndexLinear, A)
    s = zero(eltype(A))
    for i in eachindex(A)
        s += A[i]
    end
    return s
end

function _sum(::IndexCartesian, A)
    s = zero(eltype(A))
    for I in CartesianIndices(A)
        s += A[I]
    end
    return s
end

# Trait for numeric types
struct IsNumeric end
struct NotNumeric end

NumericTrait(::Type{<:Number}) = IsNumeric()
NumericTrait(::Type) = NotNumeric()

function safe_mean(collection)
    _mean(NumericTrait(eltype(collection)), collection)
end

function _mean(::IsNumeric, collection)
    return sum(collection) / length(collection)
end

function _mean(::NotNumeric, collection)
    error("Cannot compute mean of non-numeric type $(eltype(collection))")
end

# Composition of traits
struct SupportsArithmetic end
struct NoArithmetic end

ArithmeticTrait(T::Type) = method_exists(+, (T, T)) ? SupportsArithmetic() : NoArithmetic()

# Advanced trait with type parameters
abstract type StorageOrder end
struct RowMajor <: StorageOrder end
struct ColumnMajor <: StorageOrder end

StorageOrder(::Type{<:Array}) = ColumnMajor()

function optimize_iteration(A::AbstractMatrix, f::Function)
    _iterate(StorageOrder(typeof(A)), A, f)
end

function _iterate(::ColumnMajor, A, f)
    for j in 1:size(A, 2)
        for i in 1:size(A, 1)
            f(A[i, j])
        end
    end
end

function _iterate(::RowMajor, A, f)
    for i in 1:size(A, 1)
        for j in 1:size(A, 2)
            f(A[i, j])
        end
    end
end

type_stability.description: Type stability ensures functions return consistent types for given input types, enabling Julia's compiler to generate efficient code
type_stability.whenToUse: Use when optimizing performance-critical code, building libraries, ensuring predictable behavior, or eliminating runtime type checks
type_stability.example:
# Type unstable function (bad)
function unstable_parse(s::String)
    if occursin(".", s)
        return parse(Float64, s)  # Returns Float64
    else
        return parse(Int, s)      # Returns Int
    end
end

# Type stable alternatives
# Option 1: Always return the same type
function stable_parse_float(s::String)
    return parse(Float64, s)
end

# Option 2: Use Union types when necessary
function stable_parse_union(s::String)::Union{Int,Float64}
    if occursin(".", s)
        return parse(Float64, s)
    else
        return parse(Int, s)
    end
end

# Option 3: Parameterize by output type
function stable_parse(::Type{T}, s::String) where T<:Number
    return parse(T, s)
end

# Type stability with containers
function type_stable_accumulate(data::Vector{T}) where T
    # Use zero(T) to ensure type stability
    total = zero(T)
    count = 0
    
    for value in data
        total += value
        count += 1
    end
    
    # Ensure we return the same type
    return count > 0 ? total / T(count) : zero(T)
end

# Avoiding type instability in conditionals
function stable_default(x::Union{T,Nothing}, default::T) where T
    return x === nothing ? default : x
end

# Type stable error handling
struct Result{T,E}
    value::Union{T,Nothing}
    error::Union{E,Nothing}
    is_ok::Bool
    
    Result{T,E}(value::T) where {T,E} = new{T,E}(value, nothing, true)
    Result{T,E}(error::E) where {T,E} = new{T,E}(nothing, error, false)
end

function safe_divide(x::T, y::T) where T<:AbstractFloat
    if y == zero(T)
        return Result{T,String}("Division by zero")
    else
        return Result{T,String}(x / y)
    end
end

# Type assertions for performance
function optimized_sum(arr::Vector)
    s = 0.0
    for x in arr
        # Type assertion helps compiler
        s += x::Float64
    end
    return s
end

# Function barriers for type stability
function process_data(data)
    # Type unstable part
    processed = prepare_data(data)
    
    # Call type-stable inner function
    return _process_stable(processed)
end

function _process_stable(data::Vector{Float64})
    # Now everything is type stable
    return sum(data) / length(data)
end

# Maintaining type stability with missing values
function handle_missing(data::Vector{Union{T,Missing}}) where T
    total = zero(T)
    count = 0
    
    for value in data
        if !ismissing(value)
            total += value
            count += 1
        end
    end
    
    return count > 0 ? total / count : missing
end

composition_pattern.description: Composition in Julia favors combining behaviors through field embedding and delegation rather than inheritance, promoting flexible and modular design
composition_pattern.whenToUse: Use when building complex types from simpler ones, avoiding deep inheritance hierarchies, implementing has-a relationships, or creating modular interfaces
composition_pattern.example:
# Composition through fields
struct Engine
    horsepower::Int
    cylinders::Int
end

struct Wheels
    count::Int
    size::Float64
end

struct Car
    engine::Engine
    wheels::Wheels
    model::String
end

# Delegation pattern
function start(engine::Engine)
    println("Starting $(engine.cylinders)-cylinder engine with $(engine.horsepower) HP")
end

# Delegate to composed object
start(car::Car) = start(car.engine)

# Mixin-like behavior with multiple composition
mutable struct Position
    x::Float64
    y::Float64
end

mutable struct Velocity
    vx::Float64
    vy::Float64
end

mutable struct Sprite
    image::String
    width::Int
    height::Int
end

# Compose multiple behaviors
mutable struct GameObject
    position::Position
    velocity::Velocity
    sprite::Sprite
    active::Bool
end

# Define operations on components
move!(pos::Position, vel::Velocity, dt::Float64) = begin
    pos.x += vel.vx * dt
    pos.y += vel.vy * dt
end

# Delegate to components
move!(obj::GameObject, dt::Float64) = move!(obj.position, obj.velocity, dt)

# Interface-like composition
abstract type Component end

struct Transform <: Component
    position::Vector{Float64}
    rotation::Float64
    scale::Float64
end

struct Renderer <: Component
    mesh::String
    material::String
end

struct Entity
    id::Int
    components::Dict{DataType, Component}
end

# Add/get components
function add_component!(entity::Entity, component::T) where T<:Component
    entity.components[T] = component
end

function get_component(entity::Entity, ::Type{T}) where T<:Component
    return get(entity.components, T, nothing)
end

# Functional composition
struct Pipeline{T<:Tuple}
    functions::T
end

Pipeline(fs...) = Pipeline(fs)

function (pipe::Pipeline)(x)
    result = x
    for f in pipe.functions
        result = f(result)
    end
    return result
end

# Usage
process = Pipeline(
    x -> x .^ 2,
    x -> x .+ 1,
    x -> sqrt.(x)
)

# Trait-based composition
struct Drawable end
struct Updatable end
struct Collidable end

# Types can have multiple traits
traits(::Type{GameObject}) = (Drawable(), Updatable(), Collidable())

# Forward method calls to composed fields
Base.getindex(car::Car, key::Symbol) = begin
    if key == :horsepower
        return car.engine.horsepower
    elseif key == :wheel_count
        return car.wheels.count
    else
        error("Unknown property: $key")
    end
end

performance_patterns.description: Performance patterns in Julia leverage type specialization, vectorization, and memory layout optimization to achieve C-like performance
performance_patterns.whenToUse: Use when optimizing hot paths, processing large datasets, minimizing allocations, or achieving maximum computational efficiency
performance_patterns.example:
# Preallocate buffers to avoid allocations
function efficient_matrix_multiply!(C::Matrix{T}, A::Matrix{T}, B::Matrix{T}) where T
    m, n = size(A)
    n2, p = size(B)
    
    @assert n == n2 "Matrix dimensions must match"
    @assert size(C) == (m, p) "Output matrix has wrong size"
    
    # Use @inbounds to skip bounds checking in hot loop
    @inbounds for j in 1:p
        for i in 1:m
            Cij = zero(T)
            for k in 1:n
                Cij += A[i,k] * B[k,j]
            end
            C[i,j] = Cij
        end
    end
    return C
end

# Memory layout optimization
struct ColumnMajorMatrix{T}
    data::Vector{T}
    rows::Int
    cols::Int
end

# Access pattern optimized for Julia's column-major layout
function column_major_sum(mat::Matrix{T}) where T
    total = zero(T)
    @inbounds for j in 1:size(mat, 2)
        for i in 1:size(mat, 1)
            total += mat[i, j]  # Column-major access
        end
    end
    return total
end

# SIMD vectorization
function simd_dot_product(x::Vector{T}, y::Vector{T}) where T
    @assert length(x) == length(y)
    s = zero(T)
    @simd for i in eachindex(x, y)
        @inbounds s += x[i] * y[i]
    end
    return s
end

# Avoid type instability in hot loops
function stable_accumulate(data::Vector{T}, op::F) where {T, F<:Function}
    isempty(data) && return zero(T)
    
    result = data[1]
    @inbounds for i in 2:length(data)
        result = op(result, data[i])
    end
    return result
end

# Use views to avoid copying
function process_chunks(data::Vector{T}, chunk_size::Int) where T
    results = T[]
    
    for i in 1:chunk_size:length(data)
        chunk_end = min(i + chunk_size - 1, length(data))
        # Use view instead of data[i:chunk_end] to avoid allocation
        chunk_view = @view data[i:chunk_end]
        push!(results, process_chunk(chunk_view))
    end
    
    return results
end

# In-place operations
function normalize!(v::Vector{T}) where T<:AbstractFloat
    n = norm(v)
    if n > 0
        # Vectorized in-place operation
        v ./= n
    end
    return v
end

# Cache-friendly algorithms
function tiled_multiply!(C::Matrix{T}, A::Matrix{T}, B::Matrix{T}, tile_size::Int=64) where T
    m, k = size(A)
    k2, n = size(B)
    @assert k == k2
    
    # Process in tiles for better cache usage
    @inbounds for jj in 1:tile_size:n
        for ii in 1:tile_size:m
            for kk in 1:tile_size:k
                # Process tile
                for j in jj:min(jj+tile_size-1, n)
                    for i in ii:min(ii+tile_size-1, m)
                        Cij = C[i,j]
                        for k in kk:min(kk+tile_size-1, k)
                            Cij += A[i,k] * B[k,j]
                        end
                        C[i,j] = Cij
                    end
                end
            end
        end
    end
    return C
end

# Benchmark and profile
using BenchmarkTools

function optimized_function(data)
    # Use @btime to measure performance
    # @btime optimized_function($data)
    
    # Use type annotations in critical paths
    result::Float64 = 0.0
    
    # Hoist invariants out of loops
    scaling_factor = 1.0 / length(data)
    
    @fastmath @inbounds for x in data
        result += x * scaling_factor
    end
    
    return result
end

broadcast_pattern.description: Broadcasting (dot syntax) in Julia enables vectorized operations on arrays and scalars with automatic size promotion and fusion for optimal performance
broadcast_pattern.whenToUse: Use for element-wise operations on arrays, avoiding explicit loops, fusing multiple operations, or writing generic code that works with scalars and arrays
broadcast_pattern.example:
# Basic broadcasting with dot syntax
function array_operations(x::Vector{Float64}, y::Vector{Float64})
    # Element-wise operations
    z = x .+ y .* 2.0
    
    # Fused broadcast - single loop, no temporaries
    @. z = sin(x) + cos(y) * exp(-x^2)
    
    return z
end

# Broadcasting with custom functions
clamp_positive(x) = max(0.0, x)

function process_data(data::Matrix{Float64})
    # Broadcast custom function
    positive_data = clamp_positive.(data)
    
    # Multiple operations fused
    result = @. log(1 + positive_data) / (1 + exp(-positive_data))
    
    return result
end

# Broadcasting with mixed dimensions
function normalize_columns(matrix::Matrix{T}) where T
    # Calculate mean and std for each column
    col_means = mean(matrix, dims=1)  # 1×n matrix
    col_stds = std(matrix, dims=1)    # 1×n matrix
    
    # Broadcast automatically handles dimension expansion
    normalized = @. (matrix - col_means) / (col_stds + eps(T))
    
    return normalized
end

# Custom broadcasting behavior
struct Polynomial{T}
    coeffs::Vector{T}
end

# Define broadcasting for custom type
function Base.broadcasted(::typeof(evaluate), p::Polynomial, x)
    # Horner's method for polynomial evaluation
    result = zero(x)
    for i in length(p.coeffs):-1:1
        result = @. result * x + p.coeffs[i]
    end
    return result
end

# Lazy broadcasting with broadcast styles
struct LazyArray{T,N} <: AbstractArray{T,N}
    f::Function
    size::NTuple{N,Int}
end

Base.size(A::LazyArray) = A.size
Base.getindex(A::LazyArray, I...) = A.f(I...)

# Custom broadcast style
struct LazyStyle <: Broadcast.BroadcastStyle end
Base.BroadcastStyle(::Type{<:LazyArray}) = LazyStyle()

# In-place broadcasting
function update_weights!(weights::Matrix{T}, gradients::Matrix{T}, 
                        learning_rate::T) where T
    # In-place broadcast update
    @. weights -= learning_rate * gradients
    
    # More complex in-place operation
    @. weights = clamp(weights - learning_rate * gradients, -1, 1)
    
    return weights
end

# Broadcast with indices
function distance_from_center(shape::Tuple{Int,Int})
    m, n = shape
    cx, cy = m/2, n/2
    
    # Use CartesianIndices with broadcasting
    indices = CartesianIndices(shape)
    distances = map(indices) do idx
        i, j = Tuple(idx)
        sqrt((i - cx)^2 + (j - cy)^2)
    end
    
    return distances
end

# Advanced fusion with multiple arrays
function fused_operations(a::Array{T}, b::Array{T}, c::Array{T}) where T
    # Single fused loop for multiple operations
    result = similar(a)
    @. result = (sin(a) * cos(b) + tan(c)) / (1 + abs(a * b * c))
    
    # Conditional broadcasting
    mask = a .> 0
    result[mask] .= sqrt.(result[mask])
    
    return result
end

# Broadcasting with structured arrays
struct Point3D
    x::Float64
    y::Float64
    z::Float64
end

# Enable broadcasting for custom struct
Base.broadcastable(p::Point3D) = Ref(p)

# Define arithmetic operations
Base.:+(p1::Point3D, p2::Point3D) = Point3D(p1.x+p2.x, p1.y+p2.y, p1.z+p2.z)
Base.:*(s::Number, p::Point3D) = Point3D(s*p.x, s*p.y, s*p.z)

# Now can use broadcasting
function scale_points(points::Vector{Point3D}, scale::Float64)
    return scale .* points
end
